11:17 am
BE11:17am

Boris Johnson is set to suspend UK parliament for at least a month in order to curtail the efforts of MPs hoping to pass legislation to avoid a no-deal Brexit on October 31.

MPs will return next week after their summer break but parliament is expected to be suspended for longer than usual during the party conference season and ahead of a fresh Queen’s Speech, scheduled for October 14. 

Senior Downing Street officials confirmed to the FT that parliament would return on September 3 “as timetabled” but would probably be suspended again early the following week, possibly on September 9 or 10. It will not return until October 14.

The prime minister has failed to rule out proroguing parliament several times and insisted that “politicians don’t get to choose which public votes they respect”. A cross-party agreement was struck on Tuesday to bring forward legislation next week that would force Mr Johnson to request another extension to Article 50.

Shrink Good Afternoon

BE11:21am

News broke this morning that the UK government would be requesting that the sovereign suspend parliament from September 10 thereby ending the current parliamentary session until October 14. Although we have been arguing that the odds of a WTO Brexit have been very high for long time, this is an angle we had missed, despite the fact that section 2.24 of the Cabinet Manual, as far as we can tell, makes the case for prorogation quite clear.

BE11:21am

(@marktime: hello from Scotland.)

BE11:21am

The logic of the move makes sense to us. On one side, prorogation strengthens the government's negotiating hand with Brussels (though we have serious doubts that Brussels will "blink" anyway). On the other side, prorogation also allows the government to further accelerate its WTO Brexit planning. Whereas before we were arguing that the next 1-2M would see 1) a no confidence motion leading to, 2) new elections and 3) a WTO Brexit, it now looks like the calculus will yield 1) prorogation, 2) a new parliamentary session, 3) a no confidence motion in mid-October, 4) Brexit on October 31 and 5) new elections in November.

2s10s UK Gilt yields lower by 2-4 bps across the term structure.
marktime What we need is certainty, I think

BE11:25am

JP Morgan:

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Many MP’s will be outraged by the use of what is supposedly an administrative procedure to limit their ability
to express views and direct the executive. It is possible that MPs could seek to change the law to prevent
prorogation occurring when they return next week, but if the Sovereign has already agreed to the PM’s request
that creates difficulties of interaction with their authority. A case sponsored by Gina Miller is progressing
through the courts and may be accelerated given today’s news, but the ability of that to counteract a prorogation
the Sovereign has already announced is unclear.
The effect of this decision will likely be to concentrate the minds of those MPs who wish to stop no-deal, such
that the Commons time available from September 3rd is used effectively. Yesterday, opposition leader Corbyn
agreed that legislation compelling the PM to seek an Article 50 extension would be the first route MPs would
try. A vote of no-confidence in the PM followed by his replacement remains a fall-back option, but one which
many Conservative MPs will try to avoid.
For some time, we have been writing that we expected Johnson as PM would call for a general election as it
became clear his push toward “no deal” would be thwarted by the Commons. We continue to think that is the
most likely path, and today’s news will serve to intensify the focus on the actions of MPs in the coming days.
We will write more on how the spectrum of probabilities is changing as the reaction to today’s announcement
becomes clear.

BE11:26am

A final thought. What does PM Johnson gain by announcing this course of action at this point? One view is that
it is a win-win for him on the following grounds: first, it limits the ability of the Commons to prevent him
pursuing his approach to Brexit (assuming the prorogation holds). Second, if the prorogation is somehow
prevented, or legislation is passed to stop no-deal, it sets up PM Johnson as the ‘deliverer of the will of the
people’ against a ‘remainer’ House of Commons, a position he would take into a general election campaign.
From the point of view of MPs who wish to prevent no-deal, however, the message that the PM will use all the
tools available to him to push in that direction should now be very clear

marktime At least Britain IS Working, even if it is from home with the kids drowning the cockapoo in the garden

A detailed constituency-level analysis suggests Tories
would be on track for a slim majority in a snap election
 Despite parties against a no-deal enjoying a larger share
of the popular vote
 This would give the government a mandate for no-deal
 But the picture could yet change if moderate Conservative
voters were to shift support to the Lib Dems

Irish HF guy @AMS HF guy, morning, I see your username has a distinct similarity to mine, albeit you are on the continent I would imagine, (Amsterdam) whereas I am based on an Island on the periphery of Europe!
BE11:29am

The polls might yet change significantly, but if an early election
were called then our analysis based on recent polling
suggests that parties willing to pursue a no deal would get a
majority (Table 1)—and potentially without the Conservatives
requiring support from the Brexit Party. This is the same result
that emerged from our simpler aggregate model. Although
we acknowledge the level of uncertainty highlighted by
the two uniform swing approaches described above, Table 1
shows that in both cases the Conservatives are on course for a
majority, which would likely require them gaining around 323
seats. The GE17 model is admittedly close to this threshold,
but there would also be the possibility of support from the
Northern Irish DUP party again—who picked up ten seats in
2017. The EE19 model suggests the Conservatives could win
by a comfortable margin.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Petrofac reported 1H19 results, beating consensus EBITDA expectations (+11%) driven by better EPS margins. The balance sheet was also a positive surprise vs. consensus/GS expectations, with Petrofac maintaining a net cash position of $69mn despite expectations for working capital to unwind in 1H19 before improving in 2H19. Strong EBITDA performance implies the company has already achieved c.55% of FY19 consensus expectations but the company expects 1H-weighted profitability. We also see some downside risk to E&C FY19 revenue consensus expectations given low revenue coverage vs. this point last year. We remain Neutral rated.

2s10s Anti prorogue petition is going viral, https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/269157

or MOST.

BE11:37am

We expect a positive market reaction to Petrofac's 1H results with EBITDA of $305m a 13% beat to consensus and net cash balance of $69m vs guidance of $100m net debt.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Revenue of $2,821m was in-line.

BE11:38am

We expect outlook on awards in 2H and working capital movements to remain a key focus. Order intake: The company had already guided for low order intake during 1H, which came in at $1.8bn implying a book to bill of 0.7x, leaving backlog at $8.6bn.

BE11:38am

Petrofac has secured $2.6bn of revenue for 2H19, which could imply a 5% downwards revision to estimates, yet we see lower risk of revisions to EBTIDA with a strong 1H.

Irish HF guy Just looked up loungers, A "Lounge" is a neighbourhood café/bar combining elements of a restaurant, British pub and coffee shopculture. Well certainly a large addressable market! I bought some Marstons after Greene King highlighted value in the sector.
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Guidance: Petrofac maintained guidance of E&C, expecting revenue of $4.5bn and net margin at lower end of the range [~6%].

BE11:38am

Capex maintained at $125m. Profitability expected to be 1H-weighted. Cash flow: OpCF of $190m with working capital an $11m outflow. FCF of $123m ($113m excluding $10m received from non-controlling interest) including capex of $45m. DPS of $0.127 broadly in-line with consensus at $0.125

BE11:39am

And Kelper.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

There were no big surprises in the H1 report, while overall earnings were
slightly better than anticipated in terms of net profit and cash. The
guidance was broadly confirmed, and Petrofac’s (PFC) tendering pipeline
remains important.

BE11:39am

In H1, the commercial dynamic was impacted by recent issues in Saudi
Arabia and Iraq (impact from SFO investigation) and PFC has secured
USD2bn of orders YTD. Looking forward, the company has a “busy
tendering pipeline” with USD1bn of bid opportunities due to be awarded for
H2 2019. On the SFO side, PFC reaffirmed that “no charges have been
brought against PFC, or any officers or current employees”. The company is
“focused on bringing this matter to closure as quickly as possible”.

marktime Very good, it is all in the pipeline
BE11:39am

Globally, H1 results slightly exceeded expectations. The top line reached
USD2.82bn (USD2.79bn expected), with EBITDA at USD305m (USD274m
expected) and net income at USD154m (USD147m expected),
representing a net income margin of 5.5%. By business unit, the net profit
margin of the E&C division came in slightly below expectations at 6.5%
(6.8% expected), while revenues were slightly above at USD2.28bn
meaning that the net profit figure is perfectly in line at USD148m. The EPS
business unit generated a net profit margin of 5.1%, in line with
expectations, and the IES unit generated better profit than forecasted
(positive while we expected it to come in at breakeven). In terms of cash
flow, FCF was sound at USD123m and the net cash position was better
than anticipated by the company at USD69m (it was guiding for a net debt
position), reflecting “better than expected working capital inflows”. The group
will distribute an interim dividend of 12.7cents, in line with last year.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Looking forward, the 2019 guidance was broadly confirmed. In the E&C
division, revenues are expected to approach USD4.5bn and margins are
seen at the low end of the guidance range. Overall, H2 profitability is
expected to decline versus H1 (same seasonality as last year). For 2020E,
PFC expects the top line to decline, in line with consensus expectations.

BE11:40am

We have a Buy rating and 620p TP based on an SOP (8-9x EV/EBITDA
2020E).

mutant_dog O/T: Reuters has a lovely piece on fake gold bars - the gold is real but the imprimatur is fake.
Irish HF guy Also interesting, Loungers average passing rent per square metre is £295 for a Lounge and £300 for a Cosy Club and rents averaged circa five per cent. of sales between FY16 and FY18. Just 5% of sales on Rent is very good, NewRiver aiming for 7% or so, whilst INTU charged above 10% to 12% (I knew I could get INTU or Hammerson into my chat!)
BE11:41am

And Caz, who are neutral.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Petrofac delivered a good set of 1H19 underlying results, revenue beat our
forecast by 5% (beat BBG consensus by 1%), 1H 19 EBITDA of $305m
(55% FY19 consensus) beat our forecast by 6% (Bloomberg consensus by
12%) benefitting from $9m due to IFRS16 which is likely not in consensus
(2% beat to JPMe ex IFRS16), and implied a margin of 10.8% (JPMe
10.8%), while adjusted net profit of $154m (53% FY19 consensus) beat
our forecast by a 5% (and consensus by just 1%). However the company
played down the near term outlook seeing 1H stronger than 2H (in line
with consensus) with EPS margins and oil price playing a part and seeing
revenue declining in 2020 (company complied consensus revenues fall 3%
yoy, though there could be downside to this estimate if 2H orders miss
expectations). 1H19 E&C NPAT margin of 6.5% was inline with guidance
(low end of the range). YTD order intake improved to $2bn mostly given
recent EPS awards in the North Sea, the company is competing on $13bn
E&C in rest of the week year, and requires a healthy win rate to reach
targeted 1x BtB for 2019. Period end net cash $69m was better than trading
statement guidance ($0.1bn net debt). PFC continues to asses non core
disposals to further strengthen its net cash position. Interim dividend is flat
year on year at 12.7c. Finally, we note that there is no update on the SFO
was given. Overall we see 1H19 as a period of good execution, but we see
a need for shares to arrest backlog decline to outperform the sector in 2H.

marktime How do you arrest a backlog decline
BE11:43am

In a universe of cheap stocks, I'm never sure why people choose the ones under investigation by the Serious Fraud Office as if playing the outcome there represents anything more informed than gambling, but whatever I guess.

Maiden results came in ahead of expectations underpinning
forecasts and delivering on the strategy set out at IPO.
Momentum has been maintained into the new financial year
with eight openings bringing the total portfolio to 154, and
with a strong pipeline to maintain a 25pa opening rate.
Loungers’ all-day café-bar concept continues to appeal to a
broad demographic with LFL sales growth outpacing the
market. A low capex/opex model drives both high returns
and fast paybacks and the headroom for expansion is vast,
backed up by an unrivalled track record. BUY

11:45 am

BE11:46am

FY19 results highlights
• Revenue +26.4% to £153.0m
driven by 6.9% LFL & 25 new sites
• Adj EBITDA +23.7% to £20.6m
(est £20.3m), EBIT £10.2m (est
£9.6m). FCF generation strong
£17.1m (est £14.0m). Pro forma
net debt/EBITDA 1.3x.
• Current trading in line, 25 opening
target reiterated.

BE11:46am

High quality growth
• Volume-driven growth, all-day
• On-going brand development with
innovation in menu, service and
amenity.
• Openings cover a broader
geography with significant scope
to infill and expand regions
• Property discipline retained

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Upside potential
• LFL sales growth continues to
outpace the market. Our forecasts
of 4.0% this year is cautiously set
with an AGM update due October.
• Supplier renegotiations will benefit
gross margin from 2H, annualised
savings of c£1.25m.
• Brexit preparations to secure
supplies, no behavioural changes.

BE11:46am

Forecasts and valuation
• Small changes to forecasts, which
4 months into the year, are well
underpinned.
• Importantly, we expect Loungers
to be able to self-finance its 25
new openings this year.
• Current valuation is undemanding
given track record. TP of 275p.

BE11:47am

Recent and planned new openings:
• Panero Lounge, Portsmouth (May 19)

• Cosy Club, Durham (July 19)

• Cobrizo Lounge, Newbury (coming soon)
• Olmo Lounge, Huntingdon (coming soon)
• Cosy Club, Basingstoke (coming soon)

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Peel Hunt:

BE11:51am

Strong momentum continues 2019 EBITDA is in line, up 25% to £18.3m (after pre-opening costs) vs our forecast of £18.2m, with LFL sales up 6.9%. LFL sales have remained strong in early 2020E, a year for which we are forecasting 23% EBITDA growth, despite minimal change in forecast net debt. We are holding our forecasts, but believe our 2020E assumptions of 3.6% LFL sales and stable margins offer attractive upgrade risk.

BE11:52am

LFL sales rose by 6.9% in 2019, with H2 LFL sales up 7.3% by our estimates, despite the 2019E financial year not including all the Easter weekend. We believe LFL volume growth was c4% in 2019, in line with the average of the last three years. EBITDA margins (post pre-opening and central costs) fell by 10bps, with proportional pre-opening costs down 20bps. Before pre-opening costs, EBITDA rose by 24% to £20.6m, with the margin down 30bps to 13.45% reflecting higher labour costs, pensions and business rates (-70bps), offset by lower proportional central costs (+40bps). We forecast stable margins in 2020E, supported by strong LFL sales growth, increasing scale economies and recent price increases (summer menu prices increased by 2.1% for drinks and by 2.9% for food) and greater trading up opportunities. Last year, 25 sites opened, comprising 22 Lounges and three Cosy Clubs, taking the estate to 146 sites. The average cost per new site remained at £0.7m, with new sites performing in line with management’s expectations. Across the group, rent stayed at just 5.2% of sales, and pro forma net debt, at £26.7m, was slightly lower than we forecast (vs a £42.5m facility). Some 25 new openings are expected this year. We are holding our forecasts, which have absorbed investment in infrastructure, and the IT and property teams in particular. The company has also implemented new property maintenance, labour scheduling and HR software over the last year.

Irish HF guy 3rd September 2019 80th anniversary of start of WWII. How unfortunate timing
11:52 am
BE11:52am

We believe Loungers has carried strong LFL sales and pricing momentum in 2020E, as well as the benefits of recent contract re-tendering. The company should quantify its H1 2020E LFL sales when it announces its AGM statement in mid-October; an event that we expect to act as a positive catalyst for the shares.
